@graph.headline: LLC vs S-Corp in Texas: Which is Right for You?
@graph.description: Complete guide comparing LLC vs S-Corp in Texas. Learn formation costs, self-employment tax savings at different income levels, and when to elect S-Corp status for your business.
keywords: s corp vs llc taxes texas

mainEntity.name: Can I switch from an LLC to an S-Corp in Texas?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. Your LLC remains an LLC under Texas lawâ€”you're simply changing how it's taxed. File IRS Form 2553 by March 15 to elect S-Corp status for the current tax year.

mainEntity.name: Does Texas charge different Franchise Tax for S-Corps?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. Texas Franchise Tax treatment is identical for LLCs and S-Corps. Both use the same forms, rates, and the $2.47 million no-tax-due threshold (2025).

mainEntity.name: What happens if I set my S-Corp salary too low?

acceptedAnswer.text: The IRS can reclassify distributions as wages, forcing you to pay back payroll taxes plus penalties and interest. 'Reasonable salary' audits are a known enforcement priority.

mainEntity.name: Can my LLC have multiple owners and elect S-Corp status?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. Multi-member LLCs can elect S-Corp status, but all members must meet eligibility requirements: U.S. citizens or residents, no corporate or partnership shareholders, and a maximum of 100 shareholders.

mainEntity.name: Should I form a corporation instead of an LLC in Texas?

acceptedAnswer.text: For most Texas small businesses, forming an LLC and electing S-Corp taxation provides the best of both worlds: LLC liability protection and operational flexibility with S-Corp tax savings.
